source.name: City of Phoenix Public Works Department
source.notes: Based on official City of Phoenix Public Works recycling guidelines. Phoenix uses blue bin for recycling with weekly collection. Clean pizza boxes are accepted. Items under 2.5 inches cannot be recycled.

materials.name: Plastic bottles
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap (caps stay on in Phoenix)
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Phoenix accepts hard plastic bottles with caps on
Caps left on prevent them from falling through sorting screens
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with liquid still in them
Soft/squeezable tubes are not accepted

materials.name: Plastic containers and tubs
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Hard/rigid plastics only; no soft or flexible plastics
Must be larger than 2.5 inches in all dimensions
commonMistakes: No foam/styrofoam containers
No soft plastics or bags
Items smaller than 2.5 inches fall through sorting screens

materials.name: Plastic cups
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Rigid plastic cups accepted in Phoenix blue bin
commonMistakes: No foam/styrofoam cups
Straws are too small; trash them

materials.name: Plastic clamshell containers
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Clear rigid plastic clamshells accepted in Phoenix
commonMistakes: No foam clamshells
Must be rigid plastic, not foam

materials.name: Plastic lids
instructions: Snap lid back onto container if possible
Or place loose in blue recycling bin if larger than 2.5 inches
notes: Phoenix accepts plastic lids including coffee cup lids
Lids smaller than 2.5 inches should be attached to a container
commonMistakes: Tiny lids under 2.5 inches fall through sorting screens; attach to container or trash

materials.name: Aluminum cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Aluminum is infinitely recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't crush cans; it makes sorting harder
Don't include cans with food residue

materials.name: Aluminum foil and trays
instructions: Clean off all food residue
Ball foil into at least softball size
Place balled foil or clean trays in blue recycling bin
notes: Phoenix requires foil to be balled to at least softball size so it doesn't fall through sorting screens
Foil trays and pie tins are accepted if clean
commonMistakes: Don't recycle small scraps of foil; ball them together first
Heavily soiled foil should go in trash

materials.name: Steel and tin cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Labels can stay on
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Steel/tin cans are magnetically separated at the sorting facility
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food still in them

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
instructions: Empty and rinse
Remove lids and caps from glass containers
Place glass only in blue recycling bin
Metal lids can go in blue bin separately
notes: Phoenix accepts glass bottles and jars curbside in the blue bin
Lids must be removed from glass containers (unlike plastic bottles where caps stay on)
commonMistakes: Remove lids from glass jars before recycling
No broken glass in blue bin; wrap and trash it
No window glass, mirrors, ceramics, or drinking glasses

materials.name: Cardboard
instructions: Break down and flatten all boxes
Remove packing materials (styrofoam, bubble wrap)
Place in or beside blue recycling bin
notes: Phoenix requires cardboard to be broken down flat
commonMistakes: Don't include cardboard soaked with grease
Remove all packing materials from inside

materials.name: Cereal and food boxes
instructions: Remove plastic liner bag (trash the liner)
Flatten the box
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Phoenix requires plastic liners to be removed
commonMistakes: Don't forget to remove the plastic liner bag
Liner goes in trash, box goes in blue bin

materials.name: Office paper
instructions: Place in blue recycling bin
No need to remove staples or paper clips
notes: All clean, dry paper is recyclable in Phoenix
commonMistakes: Don't include paper towels, napkins, or tissues
Don't include food-soiled paper

materials.name: Junk mail and catalogs
instructions: Place directly in blue recycling bin
No need to remove windows from envelopes
notes: All paper mail is recyclable in Phoenix
commonMistakes: Don't shred unless necessary; flat paper is easier to recycle

materials.name: Envelopes
instructions: Place in blue recycling bin
Plastic windows are OK; no need to remove them
notes: Phoenix explicitly accepts envelopes with plastic windows
commonMistakes: Padded envelopes with bubble wrap lining go in trash, not recycling

materials.name: Magazines
instructions: Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Glossy paper is accepted in Phoenix recycling
commonMistakes: Don't bag magazines in plastic

materials.name: Newspaper
instructions: Place in blue recycling bin
Inserts and ads can stay inside
notes: All newsprint accepted in Phoenix blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't bag newspapers in plastic bags

materials.name: Pizza boxes
instructions: Clean pizza boxes go in blue recycling bin
Remove any leftover food, cheese, or liner paper first
notes: Phoenix accepts clean pizza boxes for recycling; this is unusual compared to many cities
Boxes with light grease stains are OK as long as no food chunks remain
commonMistakes: Remove stuck-on food before recycling
If heavily soiled with grease and food, trash it instead

materials.name: Egg cartons (paper or plastic)
instructions: Paper or plastic egg cartons go in blue recycling bin
NO foam/styrofoam egg cartons
notes: Phoenix accepts paper and plastic egg cartons but NOT foam
Foam egg cartons must go in trash
commonMistakes: Foam/styrofoam egg cartons are NOT recyclable; trash them
Only paper or rigid plastic cartons are accepted

materials.name: Paper milk cartons
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Wax-coated paper cartons accepted in Phoenix
commonMistakes: Don't include cartons with liquid still inside

materials.name: Soup and juice boxes
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap if it has one
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Aseptic cartons (Tetra Pak style) are accepted in Phoenix
commonMistakes: Don't include boxes still containing liquid

materials.name: Packing and craft paper
instructions: Flatten or fold
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Clean packing paper and brown kraft paper are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include paper with excessive tape

materials.name: Paper bags
instructions: Flatten
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Paper bags are recyclable in Phoenix
commonMistakes: Don't include bags soiled with food or grease

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Place shredded paper in a clear plastic bag
Tie the bag closed
Place the sealed clear bag in blue recycling bin
notes: Phoenix requires shredded paper to be in a sealed clear plastic bag so it doesn't scatter
This is one of the few cases where a plastic bag goes in the blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't put loose shredded paper in the blue bin; it scatters and jams equipment
Must use a clear bag, not colored or opaque
examples: Shredded documents in a clear bag

materials.name: Wrapping paper (non-metallic)
instructions: Non-metallic wrapping paper goes in blue recycling bin
Metallic or glittery wrapping paper goes in trash
notes: Do the scrunch test: if it stays scrunched, it's paper and recyclable; if it springs back, it's metallic and trash
commonMistakes: Metallic, foil, or glittery wrapping paper is NOT recyclable
Remove tape, ribbons, and bows (trash those)

materials.name: Sticky notes
instructions: Place in blue recycling bin
notes: The adhesive on sticky notes does not interfere with recycling
commonMistakes: Don't worry about the sticky strip; it's fine for recycling

materials.name: Styrofoam / polystyrene
instructions: Place in trash
Not accepted in Phoenix recycling or at eco-stations
notes: Styrofoam is one of the most common contaminants in Phoenix recycling
This includes foam cups, plates, containers, egg cartons, and packing materials
commonMistakes: Don't put any foam/styrofoam in the blue recycling bin
Foam egg cartons are NOT the same as paper or plastic egg cartons

materials.name: Plastic bags and soft plastics
instructions: Do NOT place in blue recycling bin
Take to grocery store drop-off bins for film plastic recycling
Otherwise place in trash
notes: Plastic bags are the #1 contaminant in Phoenix recycling; they tangle in sorting machinery
Many Fry's, Walmart, and Target stores in Phoenix accept plastic bags
commonMistakes: Never bag your recyclables in plastic bags
Never put any soft/flexible plastic in the blue bin

materials.name: Paper towels, napkins, and tissues
instructions: Place in trash
Not recyclable or compostable curbside in Phoenix
notes: Paper towels and napkins have short fibers that can't be recycled
Phoenix does not have curbside composting for these items
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Food scraps and food waste
instructions: Place in regular trash container
Phoenix does NOT have curbside food waste composting
notes: Unlike some cities, Phoenix has no green bin composting program for food
Consider home composting for fruit/vegetable scraps
commonMistakes: Don't put food waste in the blue recycling bin
Phoenix does not offer curbside food composting

materials.name: Yard waste and landscape trimmings
instructions: Place in green organics container (separate from recycling and trash)
Cut branches to fit in the container
Green container is collected on a regular schedule
notes: Phoenix provides a separate green organics container specifically for yard/landscape waste
This is NOT a food composting bin; yard waste only
Green container is provided by the city for residential use
commonMistakes: Don't put food scraps in the green container; yard waste only
Don't put yard waste in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Do not put in trash or recycling
Take to a Phoenix household hazardous waste collection event
Or drop off at participating retailers (Home Depot, Batteries Plus)
Tape terminals of lithium and 9V batteries before transport
notes: Batteries can cause fires in garbage trucks and at recycling facilities
Phoenix holds periodic hazardous waste collection events by neighborhood
commonMistakes: Don't throw batteries in trash
Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Electronics and e-waste
instructions: Take to a Phoenix eco-station for free recycling
Best Buy also accepts e-waste for recycling
Delete personal data before disposal
notes: Phoenix eco-stations accept electronics for recycling at no charge
Arizona law restricts e-waste disposal in landfills
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in trash or blue bin
Wipe personal data first

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Take to a Phoenix household hazardous waste collection event
Latex paint: can dry it out with kitty litter, then trash the solid
Oil-based paint and stains: must go to hazardous waste collection
notes: Phoenix holds household hazardous waste events throughout the year
Check phoenix.gov for the next event in your area
commonMistakes: Don't pour paint down the drain
Don't put liquid paint in the trash

materials.name: Motor oil and automotive fluids
instructions: Take to a Phoenix household hazardous waste collection event
AutoZone and O'Reilly Auto Parts locations in Phoenix also accept used oil
notes: Most auto parts stores accept used motor oil for free
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains or storm drains
Don't put in trash

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Take to a DEA-authorized drug take-back location
Phoenix Police Department substations have drop-off boxes
CVS and Walgreens in Phoenix participate in take-back programs
If no drop-off available: mix with coffee grounds or kitty litter, seal in container, and trash
notes: Never flush medications down the toilet
Phoenix PD maintains permanent drug disposal boxes
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications
Don't throw loose pills in trash

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate to Goodwill, Salvation Army, or local thrift stores
Textile recycling bins are available throughout Phoenix
Worn-out items are still accepted in textile recycling bins
notes: Phoenix does not accept textiles in curbside recycling
Clothing in good condition should be donated
commonMistakes: Don't put clothing in the blue recycling bin
Don't put clothing in the trash if it can be donated

materials.name: Light bulbs
instructions: CFL and fluorescent bulbs: take to household hazardous waste event or Home Depot/Lowe's
LED bulbs: e-waste recycling at eco-station
Incandescent bulbs: wrap and place in trash
notes: CFL bulbs contain mercury and must not go in trash
Home Depot and Lowe's in Phoenix accept CFL bulbs
commonMistakes: Don't put CFL bulbs in trash or recycling
Don't break fluorescent bulbs; mercury hazard

materials.name: Candy wrappers
instructions: Place in trash
Metallized film is not recyclable
notes: Candy wrappers look metallic but are plastic film bonded with metal; not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Chip bags and snack pouches
instructions: Place in trash
Metallized plastic; not recyclable
notes: The shiny interior is aluminum laminated to plastic film; not separable
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Lined paper cups: place in trash
Plastic lids: blue recycling bin (if larger than 2.5 inches)
Paper sleeve: blue recycling bin
notes: The plastic lining inside paper cups prevents recycling of the cup itself
Separate the lid and sleeve for recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put lined paper cups in the blue bin
The lid and sleeve CAN be recycled separately

materials.name: Diapers
instructions: Bag and place in trash
notes: Not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Receipts (thermal paper)
instructions: Place in trash
Thermal paper contains BPA; do not recycle
notes: Thermal receipts contaminate paper recycling with chemical coatings
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Bubble wrap and air pillows
instructions: Place in trash
Or take to store drop-off for plastic film recycling
notes: Plastic film and bubble wrap jam recycling sorting machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Books
instructions: Donate if in good condition (library, Goodwill, thrift stores)
If damaged, place in blue recycling bin
Remove hardcover bindings with glossy laminate (trash them)
notes: Donating is always preferred over recycling
Phoenix Public Library accepts book donations
commonMistakes: Don't throw usable books in trash

materials.name: Aerosol cans
instructions: Must be completely empty
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Non-empty or pressurized aerosols are hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if still pressurized or has product inside
Partially full aerosols go to hazardous waste collection

materials.name: Cooking oil and grease
instructions: Collect in a sealed container
Take to a Phoenix household hazardous waste event
Small amounts: solidify with paper towels and trash
notes: Never pour cooking oil down the drain; it causes sewer blockages
commonMistakes: Don't pour down sink or storm drains

materials.name: Propane tanks
instructions: Take to Phoenix household hazardous waste collection event
Never put in trash or recycling
Blue Rhino exchange locations also accept old tanks
notes: Pressurized containers are fire and explosion risks in garbage trucks
commonMistakes: Never puncture propane tanks
Never put in trash or blue bin

materials.name: Needles and sharps
instructions: Place in an FDA-cleared sharps container or sturdy puncture-proof container
Take to Phoenix household hazardous waste event
Some pharmacies accept sharps containers
notes: Never place loose sharps in trash or recycling
commonMistakes: Never put loose needles in trash or recycling
Use a rigid container, not bags

materials.name: Mattress
instructions: Schedule a bulk trash pickup through Phoenix Public Works
Or take to a Phoenix transfer station
Donate if in good condition
notes: Phoenix collects bulk trash by neighborhood on a scheduled rotation
Check your neighborhood's bulk trash pickup schedule at phoenix.gov
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb outside your scheduled bulk pickup period

materials.name: Large and bulk items
instructions: Schedule bulk trash pickup through Phoenix Public Works
Bulk trash is collected by neighborhood on a rotating schedule
Or take to a Phoenix transfer station
notes: Each Phoenix neighborhood has a scheduled bulk trash collection period
Check phoenix.gov for your neighborhood's bulk trash dates
Donate usable items to Goodwill or Habitat for Humanity ReStore
commonMistakes: Don't leave items at curb outside your scheduled bulk pickup window
Don't put in regular trash container

materials.name: Chargers and cables
instructions: Take to a Phoenix eco-station or Best Buy for recycling
Do NOT put in blue recycling bin
notes: Cables and cords tangle in recycling sorting machinery and cause shutdowns
commonMistakes: Never put cables or cords in curbside recycling

materials.name: Smartphone
instructions: Factory reset and wipe personal data first
Trade in at carrier stores or Apple/Samsung stores
Take to Best Buy or a Phoenix eco-station for free recycling
notes: Many carriers and manufacturers offer trade-in credit
commonMistakes: Don't forget to wipe personal data
Don't put in trash

materials.name: Mirrors and window glass
instructions: Wrap carefully in newspaper or cardboard
Label as BROKEN GLASS
Place in trash
notes: Mirrors and window glass have different coatings than container glass and cannot be recycled with bottles/jars
commonMistakes: Never put in blue recycling bin
Never put broken glass loose in the bin

materials.name: Ceramics and dishware
instructions: Place in trash
Wrap broken pieces for safety
notes: Ceramics contaminate glass recycling; they have a different melting point
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin with glass
Ceramics are NOT the same as glass

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Take to a tire retailer or Phoenix transfer station
Most shops accept old tires when you buy new ones
notes: Tires are banned from Phoenix landfills
commonMistakes: Don't dump illegally
Don't put in bulk trash

materials.name: Ink and toner cartridges
instructions: Return to Staples or Office Depot for credit
Manufacturers offer mail-back programs
Take to a Phoenix eco-station
notes: Many stores give store credit for returned cartridges
commonMistakes: Don't throw in trash

materials.name: Fluorescent tubes
instructions: Take to Phoenix household hazardous waste collection event
Home Depot and Lowe's accept fluorescent tubes
notes: Contains mercury; handle carefully and don't break
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash
Don't break them; mercury is toxic

materials.name: Pet waste
instructions: Bag and place in trash
notes: Pet waste contains harmful pathogens; do not compost
commonMistakes: Don't put in green organics container
Don't flush cat litter

materials.name: Makeup and cosmetics
instructions: Most cosmetic containers go in trash
Clean empty rigid plastic containers (#1, #2, #5) may go in blue bin if larger than 2.5 inches
notes: Small cosmetic items typically fall below the 2.5-inch recycling threshold
commonMistakes: Small items fall through sorting screens
Nail polish is hazardous waste

materials.name: Toothbrush
instructions: Place in trash
notes: Mixed plastic; too small and not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Hangers
instructions: Place in trash
Wire hangers can be returned to dry cleaners
notes: Hangers tangle in sorting equipment and are a common contaminant
commonMistakes: Don't put hangers in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Items smaller than 2.5 inches
instructions: Place in trash
Items smaller than 2.5 inches in all dimensions cannot be recycled in Phoenix
notes: Small items fall through the screens at the recycling sorting facility
Attach small lids to their containers when possible to keep them above the 2.5-inch threshold
commonMistakes: Don't put loose small items in the blue bin
Attach bottle caps to bottles instead of tossing them separately

materials.name: Wax paper and parchment paper
instructions: Place in trash
Not recyclable due to wax coating
Phoenix has no curbside composting for these items
notes: Wax and silicone coatings prevent paper recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Fast food wrappers
instructions: Food-soiled wrappers go in trash
Clean paper wrappers can go in blue recycling bin
notes: Phoenix has no curbside composting so food-soiled paper goes to trash
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy wrappers in the blue bin

materials.name: Food-soiled cardboard
instructions: Place in trash if heavily soiled with food or grease
Lightly soiled cardboard (like pizza boxes with minor grease) may still go in blue bin
notes: Since Phoenix has no curbside composting, food-soiled cardboard goes to trash
Clean portions can be torn off and recycled
commonMistakes: Don't put heavily greasy cardboard in blue bin; it contaminates paper recycling

materials.name: Plastic utensils and straws
instructions: Place in trash
Too small and lightweight to be sorted at the recycling facility
notes: Utensils and straws fall below the 2.5-inch sorting threshold in at least one dimension
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Scrap metal
instructions: Small metal items like pots and pans: take to eco-station
Large scrap metal: take to a scrap yard or Phoenix transfer station
Empty metal food containers go in blue bin
notes: Phoenix eco-stations accept scrap metal for recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put large metal objects in the blue bin
Pots and pans are not accepted in curbside recycling

materials.name: Car batteries
instructions: Return to auto parts store (AutoZone, O'Reilly, Batteries Plus)
Arizona requires retailers to accept old batteries when selling new ones
Or take to Phoenix household hazardous waste event
notes: Lead-acid batteries are highly recyclable but extremely hazardous
commonMistakes: Never put in trash
Never put in blue bin
Handle carefully; contains sulfuric acid

recycle: Hard plastic bottles (caps on), cups, jars, jugs, tubs, lids, clamshells, containers
Aluminum foil and trays (clean, foil balled to softball size)
Office paper, junk mail, catalogs, magazines, newspapers
Egg cartons (paper or plastic only, NO foam)
Shredded paper (in sealed clear plastic bag)
trash: Candy wrappers, chip bags, snack pouches

recycle: Plastic bags, film, and soft plastics
Loose shredded paper (must be in clear bag)

tips: CAPS ON plastic bottles; LIDS OFF glass jars
Ball aluminum foil to at least softball size before recycling
Shredded paper must go in a sealed clear plastic bag
Clean pizza boxes ARE recyclable in Phoenix
Items under 2.5 inches cannot be recycled; they fall through sorting screens
Egg cartons: paper or plastic OK, foam is NEVER accepted
No curbside food composting; food scraps go in regular trash
Green container is for yard/landscape waste ONLY, not food
Check your neighborhood bulk trash schedule at phoenix.gov
Phoenix eco-stations provide free drop-off recycling for additional items

locations.name: North Gateway Eco-Station
locations.address: 27th Ave. north of Happy Valley Rd., Phoenix, AZ
locations.notes: Free for Phoenix residents with proof of residency.

locations.name: Cave Creek Eco-Station
locations.address: 2502 E. Cave Creek Rd., Phoenix, AZ

locations.name: Household Hazardous Waste Collection Events
locations.hours: Periodic events scheduled by neighborhood; check phoenix.gov for dates
locations.notes: Free for Phoenix residents. Events rotate through different parts of the city.
